ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Spanish mastery in terms of writing, speaking, and comprehension of the culture.

In this class, I improved my ability to speak Spanish, learning new vocabulary, tenses, and phrasing. I applied these skills to analyze works of art and writing, have coherent conversations with others, and create my own writing.

I learned a ton about Spanish and Latin@ culture through this course. Up until now, many of my previous Spanish classes have only surrounded language so I really enjoyed the opportunity to connect my knowledge of the language to the culture.
Applying Spanish speaking, writing, and presentation skills to discuss a variety of topics concerning the Latinamerican world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a great course. It was engaging and I learned the language.
Only strengths. Projects were great and Prof Diaz stressed the importance of group collaboration which made the process of learning a lot easier.

Strengths: A variety of ways to apply the language helped me learn better. Prof. Diaz was a huge strength, as was the level of engagement of the class. The asynchronous day was also a big strength.

Weaknesses: This class did feel more geared towards certain subjects (history, writing) which at times made me feel like I was at a disadvantage compared to others because I don't specialize in those areas.

The strength of the course was Professor Diaz' enthusiasm about everything he taught. He was incredibly excited to teach us about the culture and history of so many latin countries and it made the course even more engaging. One weakness of the course was the homework. At times we were assigned over a half a movie to watch before the next class period, which was the following day because the course was five days a week. This coupled with questions assigned to complement the movie sometimes felt like a lot when I would have homework for other classes to complete as well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, because it is a good class to learn spanish while also being fun.

If you're looking to take L4, take it with Prof Diaz. He's the best. Really detailed comments on our homework and makes classes really enjoyable. Him opening up open office hours was really nice and helpful when you need to ask him questions/or ask for him to review your work. The course content was also quite interesting too and I definitely have a stronger sense of Latin American culture and geopolitics after taking the course.
I would absolutely recommend this course to others, especially with Sebastian. I felt like I was able to learn and engage in the class comfortably without being overwhelmed.
I would recommend this course to another student! It was a lot of fun and I loved learning from Professor Diaz. I really enjoyed getting to transition beyond only learning grammar during this class.
